Chief Complaint: respiratory distress
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
    Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for upper extremity gangrene,
   underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by
   perioperative MI, was transferred to medicine for ascites and
   bradycardia, and is now transferred to MICU for management of
   hypotension and question sepsis.
   He was admitted to the vascular surgery service on [**2111-1-7**] for chronic
   bilateral finger infections and ischemic digits. He underwent bilateral
   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis
   on [**2111-1-13**] when he developed bradycardia, hypotension, demand cardic
   ischemia, and unresponsivness that required intubation and pressors.
   .
   Of note, he has developed new ascites after having been told that he
   "cleared" his Hep C years ago after tx with ribaviron/interferon in
   [**2101**] at [**Hospital1 12**]. Noted to have a significant alcohol history as well, but
   quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. Abdominal distension has been
   progressive over the last month. Had tap on [**1-13**] negative for SBP;
   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   .
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).
   - MAPs > 60
   - SVO2 > 70%
   - albumin 50 mg IV x 1 upon arrival to floor
   - vanc/zosyn; consider linezolid if decompensates given history of VRE
   - sputum, urine, blood, stool cultures
   - would consider pulling R subclav
   - check bladder pressure q6h
   - consider tap if pressures improve
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Also intubated [**Date range (1) 3633**] on
   surgery for hypotension.
   - placed on pressure control because of high PIPs on AC
   - vanc/zosyn as above
   - will place a-line for ABGs
   - will consider therapeutic para to reduce intra-abdominal pressures
   and improve respiratory mechanics
   .
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular reccs
   .
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin for volume expansion
   - will consider paracentesis if BPs stable
   - lactulose
   - liver reccs
   .
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - HD likely today
   - renal reccs
   .
   # FEN: IVFs / replete lytes prn / regular diet
   # PPX: PPI, heparin SQ, bowel regimen
   # ACCESS: PIV
   # CODE:  Full, discussed
   # CONTACT:  Brother [**Name (NI) **] (HCP) [**Numeric Identifier 10944**], [**Numeric Identifier 10945**]; [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) 4246**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 10946**]

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted to the hospital for upper extremity gangrene and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery. However, his hospital course has been complicated by multiple medical issues, including perioperative MI, asystolic cardiac arrest, and the development of new ascites. He was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: intubated and ventilated due to acute respiratory acidosis and hypercapnea
* Cardiovascular status: hypotensive with a MAP of 94/51 mmHg, requiring pressors
* Renal status: on hemodialysis three times a week
* Hepatic status: cirrhotic with a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion concerning for HCC
* Infectious status: positive for SBP on tap, with cultures pending for sputum, urine, blood, and stool
* Neurological status: not assessed

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient's positive SBP culture and meeting SIRS criteria suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis and hypotension. Close monitoring of his vital signs and hemodynamic parameters is necessary to prevent further deterioration.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory acidosis and hypercapnea may worsen if not properly managed. Close monitoring of his ABG values and adjustment of his ventilator settings as necessary are important.
3. Hepatic failure: The patient's cirrhosis and liver mass may lead to hepatic failure if not properly managed. Close monitoring of his liver function tests and consideration of liver reccs are important.
4. Renal failure: The patient's ESRD and recent hemodialysis may lead to renal failure if not properly managed. Close monitoring of his creatinine levels and consideration of further hemodialysis are important.
5. PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient's PVD and left brachial to radial bypass may lead to further complications if not properly managed. Close monitoring of his graft site and consideration of further vascular reccs are important.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and hemodynamic parameters closely to prevent further deterioration.
2. Adjust the patient's ventilator settings as necessary to improve his respiratory status.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function tests and consider liver reccs as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider further hemodialysis as necessary.
5. Consider pulling the patient's R subclav line if it becomes infected.
6. Consider therapeutic paracentesis to reduce intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's graft site and consider further vascular reccs as necessary.
8. Consider repeating the patient's liver ultrasound in three months to monitor the progression of his liver mass.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Patient Information**

* Chief complaint: Respiratory distress
* Age: 55
* Comorbidities: HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, PVD
* Recent history: Underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative MI
* Current admission: For worsening PVD and respiratory failure

**Current Status**

* Respiratory failure: Patient is on ventilator support with a PCV+Assist mode, with a PEEP of 12 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%
* Hypotension: Patient's blood pressure is 94/51 mmHg, with a MAP of 60
* Sepsis: Patient has a diagnosis of SBP, R subclavian/L HD line, PNA, and urosepsis, with no organism isolated to date
* Liver cirrhosis: Patient has cirrhosis and ascites with a 4L tap on [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI
* Liver mass: Patient has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for HCC

**Potential Medical Complications**

* Respiratory failure: Continued respiratory failure can lead to further deterioration in oxygenation and ventilation, potentially requiring more invasive respiratory support or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)
* Sepsis: Uncontrolled sepsis can lead to multi-organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, hepatic failure, and cardiovascular collapse
* Liver failure: Continued liver cirrhosis and potential liver mass can lead to further deterioration in liver function, potentially requiring liver transplantation
* Cardiac complications: Patient's history of perioperative MI and NSTEMI, combined with ongoing hypotension, can increase the risk of cardiac complications, including cardiac arrest and cardiogenic shock
* Renal failure: Patient's ESRD and ongoing sepsis can increase the risk of acute kidney injury and potential need for renal replacement therapy
* Gastrointestinal complications: Patient's history of ascites and potential liver mass can increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation

**Plan**

* Continue Vanc/Zosyn for possible SBP, PNA, and line infection
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust management accordingly
* Continue albumin PRN, and restart pressors as needed
* Attempt to decrease vent settings as tolerated
* Monitor for signs of liver failure and adjust management accordingly
* Consider further imaging while in-house, including MRI with contrast, once stable
* Continue renal replacement therapy as needed

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

* Vital signs: The patient's temperature is 103.9F (39.9C), heart rate is 105 bpm, and blood pressure is 94/51 mmHg. Respiratory rate is 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 100%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is 11 mmHg, and bladder pressure is 15 mmHg.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 349 mL of fluid and has a total output of 277 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 72 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 35 cmH2O, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 12 cmH2O, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 10.4, hemoglobin is 8.3 g/dL, platelet count is 295,000, and creatinine is 3.7 mg/dL. The patient's troponin level is 3.34, and lactate level is 0.8 mmol/L.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis: The patient's temperature is elevated, and they have a positive blood culture, which increases the risk of developing sepsis.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which may indicate acute kidney injury.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, and their respiratory rate is high, which may indicate respiratory failure.
* Septic shock: The patient's blood pressure is low, and they have a positive blood culture, which increases the risk of developing septic shock.
* Acidosis: The patient's lactate level is elevated, which may indicate acidosis.
* Respiratory acidosis: The patient's partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) is not specified, but their respiratory rate is high, which may indicate respiratory acidosis.

The patient's plan of care should include:

* Continued respiratory support with mechanical ventilation
* Antibiotic therapy for suspected sepsis
* Fluid management to prevent fluid overload
* Monitoring of laboratory results, including blood cultures, complete blood count, and electrolyte levels
* Monitoring of hemodynamic parameters, including blood pressure, central venous pressure, and bladder pressure
* Monitoring of respiratory parameters, including oxygen saturation and respiratory rate
* Consideration of dialysis therapy for acute kidney injury
* Consideration of stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.

Chief Complaint: respiratory distress
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
    Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for upper extremity gangrene,
   underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by
   perioperative MI (cards thought it was NSTEMI [**2-17**] demand). Pt  was
   transferred to medicine for ascites and bradycardia, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   He was admitted to the vascular surgery service on [**2111-1-7**] for chronic
   bilateral finger infections and ischemic digits. He underwent bilateral
   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis
   on [**2111-1-13**] when he developed bradycardia, hypotension, demand cardic
   ischemia, and unresponsivness that required intubation and pressors.
   .
   Of note, he has developed new ascites after having been told that he
   "cleared" his Hep C years ago after tx with ribaviron/interferon in
   [**2101**] at [**Hospital1 12**]. Noted to have a significant alcohol history as well, but
   quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. Abdominal distension has been
   progressive over the last month. Had tap on [**1-13**] negative for SBP;
   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.
   24 Hour Events:
   Albumin x1. Therapeutic paracentesis (1.8L) which improved ventilation
   and oxygenation (and reduced bladder pressures). Inotropes not
   required. CXR with L pleural effusion. ABG c/w acute repiratory
   acidosis. BiPap not tolerated, so intubated yesterday at 8PM. PCV for
   high PIPs.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass, which was complicated by perioperative MI. He was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient has developed new ascites, which was tapped on [**1-13**] and showed no signs of SBP. However, he developed a SBP on [**2111-1-23**] and was started on ceftriaxone. He also has a hypoechoic lesion in the liver, concerning for HCC, and a history of HCV treatment.

The patient's current condition is critical, with acute respiratory acidosis, acidemia, and hypotension. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. He has a rising WBC count and is at risk for sepsis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's rising WBC count and positive blood cultures indicate a high risk of sepsis. He is at risk for multi-organ failure and death if not properly managed.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory acidosis and acidemia require close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD and perioperative MI puts him at risk for cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
4. Liver complications: The patient's liver cirrhosis and hypoechoic lesion in the liver increase his risk for liver failure and HCC.
5. Renal complications: The patient's ESRD and history of HD put him at risk for acute kidney injury and further decline in renal function.
6. Infection: The patient's multiple lines and drains increase his risk for infection, including line sepsis and UTI.
7. Bleeding complications: The patient's history of bleeding complications, including perioperative MI, puts him at risk for further bleeding complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory values closely.
2. Administer antibiotics and antifungals as indicated by the patient's culture results.
3. Consider further imaging studies to evaluate the patient's liver and other organs.
4. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and consider further cardiac evaluation.
6. Continue to manage the patient's ESRD with HD and consider further renal evaluation.
7. Monitor the patient's wound healing and consider further wound care as needed.

* Infections: The patient has sepsis, which is likely caused by SBP, R subclavian/L HD line, PNA, and urosepsis. He is at risk for further infections due to his underlying condition and the use of invasive lines and devices.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for further respiratory failure due to his underlying condition and the use of mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is at risk for further cardiac events due to his underlying condition and the use of medications that can affect the heart.
* Kidney damage: The patient has ESRD and is at risk for further kidney damage due to his underlying condition and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
* Liver damage: The patient has cirrhosis and a liver mass, which is concerning for HCC. He is at risk for further liver damage due to his underlying condition and the use of medications that can affect the liver.
* Infections: The patient has sepsis and is at risk for further infections due to his underlying condition and the use of invasive lines and devices.

To manage the patient's condition, the following plan is in place:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medications as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal status and adjust his HD schedule as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's hepatic status and adjust his medications as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust his antibiotics as needed.
* Consider further imaging studies to evaluate the patient's liver mass and rule out other potential causes of his symptoms.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.
   24 Hour Events:
   PCV vent overnight. R IJ placed yesterday afternoon but went to
   sub-clavian on CXR and was removed without complication.

Summary:

The patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, and CAD, was admitted to the ICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure. He has a complex medical history, including a recent left brachial to radial bypass, perioperative MI, and PVD. He was transferred to the ICU from the MICU for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on January 12. The patient's condition has been complicated by ascites, bradycardia, and hypotension, which has led to the development of sepsis and respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has developed sepsis, which is likely caused by SBP, urosepsis, and possible R subclavian/L HD line infections. The patient's fever curve has improved, but the source of infection is still unclear.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has developed respiratory failure, which is likely caused by new L pleural effusion and possible pulmonary edema and pneumonia.
3. Increasing INR: The patient's INR has increased to 1.5, which may be caused by nutrition and SBP. The patient's DIC labs will be monitored, and DIC will be considered if the INR continues to rise.
4. HCV Cirrhosis/Liver Mass: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites with a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US, which is concerning for HCC. The patient's liver function will be monitored, and further imaging will be considered once stable.
5. ESRD: The patient has ESRD and is on a qMWF HD schedule. CVVH will be started today.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of perioperative MI and PVD, which may lead to cardiac complications, such as CHF with EF 20%.
7. PVD/Left Brachial to Radial Bypass/Right 4th PIP Osteomyelitis: The patient has PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass, which may lead to complications, such as graft failure and osteomyelitis.
8. Ascites: The patient has developed ascites, which may lead to complications, such as hypotension and NSTEMI.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The plan includes:

* Continuing vanc/zosyn for sepsis
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and respiratory failure
* Reversible barriers to extubation include possible pulmonary edema and pneumonia
* Daily sedation holiday and daily CXR
* Monitoring for signs of DIC and considering CVVH if necessary
* Repeating u/s in 3 months for liver mass
* Monitoring for signs of cardiac complications
* Continuing PPI, heparin SQ, and bowel regimen
* Considering further imaging for liver mass and PVD
* Monitoring for signs of ESRD complications

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic liver disease, end-stage renal disease, diabetes, coronary artery disease, and peripheral vascular disease. He was admitted for worsening peripheral vascular disease and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery, which was complicated by perioperative myocardial infarction. He is currently in the ICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 103.9F, heart rate 104 bpm, blood pressure 101/51 mmHg, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 99%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) 12 mmHg, pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) not available.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 1,173 mL of fluid and has a positive fluid balance of 1,137 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a PCV+assist mode, with a set rate of 20 breaths per minute, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 50%.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 10.4 K/uL, hemoglobin is 8.0 g/dL, and platelet count is 295 K/uL. His lactate level is 0.8 mmol/L, and his troponin-T level is 3.34 ng/mL.
* Imaging studies: The patient has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on ultrasound, which is concerning for hepatocellular carcinoma.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Sepsis/hypotension: The patient has a fever and leukocytosis, and is volume responsive, which suggests that heart failure is unlikely.
* Respiratory failure: The patient has a new left pleural effusion, which has resolved after therapeutic paracentesis.
* PVD/left brachial to radial bypass/right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient has a history of peripheral vascular disease and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery, which was complicated by perioperative myocardial infarction.
* HCV cirrhosis/liver mass: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites, and has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on ultrasound, which is concerning for hepatocellular carcinoma.
* ESRD: The patient has end-stage renal disease and is on hemodialysis.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his fever, leukocytosis, and positive fluid balance.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to his underlying lung disease and the presence of a new left pleural effusion.
* Cardiac complications: The patient is at risk for cardiac complications due to his history of myocardial infarction and the presence of a liver mass.
* Renal failure: The patient is at risk for renal failure due to his underlying kidney disease and the presence of a positive fluid balance.
* Hepatic complications: The patient is at risk for hepatic complications due to his liver disease and the presence of a liver mass.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Management of sepsis/hypotension: The patient will be treated with antibiotics and fluids, and his blood pressure will be closely monitored.
* Management of respiratory failure: The patient will be continued on mechanical ventilation, and his respiratory status will be closely monitored.
* Management of PVD/left brachial to radial bypass/right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient will be treated with antibiotics and will have regular follow-up appointments with his vascular surgeon.
* Management of HCV cirrhosis/liver mass: The patient will be treated with antiviral therapy and will have regular follow-up appointments with his liver specialist.
* Management of ESRD: The patient will continue to receive hemodialysis, and his renal function will be closely monitored.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 103.9F, heart rate of 104 bpm, and blood pressure of 101/51 mmHg. They are receiving mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient has a central venous catheter and is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and analgesics. They are also receiving nutritional support and glycemic control measures.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of chronic kidney disease, with a creatinine level of 4.2 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 47 mg/dL. Their complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell count of 10.4 x 10^9/L, a platelet count of 252 x 10^9/L, and a hemoglobin level of 8.0 g/dL.

The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.8 mEq/L and a magnesium level of 2.1 mg/dL. Their lactate level is 0.8 mmol/L, and their lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level is 103 IU/L.

The patient's imaging studies show evidence of bilateral pleural effusions and a left lower lobe infiltrate.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's chronic kidney disease and septic shock increase their risk of developing AKI.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory acidosis and septic shock increase their risk of developing respiratory failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock and chronic kidney disease increase their risk of developing sepsis.
4. DVT: The patient's central venous catheter and immobility increase their risk of developing DVT.
5. VAP: The patient's mechanical ventilation and immobility increase their risk of developing VAP.
6. Stress ulcer: The patient's septic shock and chronic kidney disease increase their risk of developing stress ulcer.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's chronic kidney disease and electrolyte imbalance increase their risk of developing hyperkalemia.
8. Hypocalcemia: The patient's chronic kidney disease and electrolyte imbalance increase their risk of developing hypocalcemia.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent these complications and improve their outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on January 12th, complicated by perioperative MI. He was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

Current vital signs:

* Temperature: 103.9F (38.9C)
* Heart rate: 104 bpm
* Blood pressure: 101/51 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Central venous pressure: 12 mmHg

The patient has developed sepsis, with fevers and climbing leukocytosis, and is suspected to have a source of infection in the subclavian vein, left HD line, PNA, and urosepsis. He is volume responsive and is being managed with IV fluids and vasopressors.

The patient also has respiratory failure, with a diagnosis of L pleural effusion that resolved after therapeutic paracentesis. He is being managed with mechanical ventilation and is on 23/12 PCV.

Other significant findings include:

* Increasing INR (1.5)
* PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass with a hypoechoic liver lesion on US, concerning for HCC
* ESRD, with a last HD on January 21st and scheduled for CVVH today

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to uncontrolled infection
* Respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock, due to his history of CAD and PVD
* Hepatic complications, such as liver failure or bleeding, due to his cirrhosis and liver mass
* Renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or worsening ESRD, due to CVVH and potential nephrotoxic medications
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation, due to his history of PVD and liver cirrhosis

Based on this information, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his sepsis, respiratory failure, and cardiac and hepatic complications.

   gangrene, underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]
   complicated by perioperative MI, was transferred to medicine for
   ascites and bradycardia, and is now transferred to MICU for management
   of hypotension and question sepsis.
   He was admitted to the vascular surgery service on [**2111-1-7**] for chronic
   bilateral finger infections and ischemic digits. He underwent bilateral
   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis
   on [**2111-1-13**] when he developed bradycardia, hypotension, demand cardic
   ischemia, and unresponsivness that required intubation and pressors.
   .
   Of note, he has developed new ascites after having been told that he
   "cleared" his Hep C years ago after tx with ribaviron/interferon in
   [**2101**] at [**Hospital1 12**]. Noted to have a significant alcohol history as well, but
   quit drinking approximately 21 years ago. Abdominal distension has been
   progressive over the last month. Had tap on [**1-13**] negative for SBP;
   cytology not sent. RUQ US on [**2111-1-20**] showed evidence of cirrhosis and
   hypoechoic lesion concerning for HCC.
   .
   He is being followed by multiple services including vascular surgery,
   plastic surgery (for finger wounds), cardiology (s/p cardiac arrest x
   3, feel he has had demand ischemia; symptomatic bradycardia ),
   nephrology (MWF HD patient), and hepatology (for ascites & new liver
   mass).
   .
   He was transferred to medicine on [**2111-1-21**].  In the two days prior to
   admission to the MICU, he was noted to have increased oxygen
   requirement (95% on 5L from 2L previously) and SBPs dropping from the
   100s -> 80s.  He underwent a diagnosis para on the day of transfer
   after receiving albumin 50g (initially planned for therapeutic tap
   given increased abdominal distention); the tap was consistent with SBP
   and he was started on ceftriaxone.

   PCV vent overnight. R IJ placed yesterday afternoon but went to
   sub-clavian on CXR and was removed without complication.

   upper extremity angiogram on [**2111-1-8**] and then left brachial to radial
   bypass w/ NR basilic vein on [**2111-1-12**]. His hospital course has been
   complicated by asystolic cardiac arrest peri-op and a 4L paracentesis

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient's condition is complex and multi-faceted. The patient is a 55-year-old man with a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD who underwent left brachial to radial bypass on January 12, 2021, complicated by perioperative MI. He was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition includes:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on ventilator support with O2 sats 100% on FIO2 0.5. The CXR shows increased interstitial edema bilaterally with density at the left base compared to January 23, 2021. There is also vague opacity in the left upper zone.
* Renal failure: The patient has ESRD and is on a qMWF HD schedule. CVVH has been started.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has stabilized with antibiotics.
* UTI: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is being treated with antibiotics.
* Suspect volume overload: The CXR evolution suggests that the patient may be experiencing volume overload, which is playing a significant role in respiratory decompensation.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis: The patient's fever curve has improved, but the patient is still at risk for sepsis given the presence of a UTI and possible pneumonia.
* Pneumonia: The patient's CXR shows increased interstitial edema bilaterally with density at the left base, which may be indicative of pneumonia.
* Volume overload: The patient's CXR evolution suggests that the patient may be experiencing volume overload, which can lead to respiratory decompensation.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD and perioperative MI puts him at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
* Liver complications: The patient's HCV cirrhosis and liver mass put him at risk for liver complications, such as liver failure or bleeding.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue antibiotics for UTI and possible pneumonia.
* Reduce FIO2 and consider switching to PSV tomorrow.
* Aim for several days of negative fluid balance with CVVH.
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and cardiac complications.
* Consider further imaging, such as MRI with contrast, to evaluate the liver mass.
* Continue lactulose for ascites.
* Consider further interventions, such as surgical exploration, to evaluate and manage the patient's abdominal distension and ventral hernia.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.
   # Respiratory failure:  Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on
   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Improved with 1.6L
   paracentesis.
   - cont to weane vent
   - vanc/zosyn
   - will consider repeat therapeutic para if needed to reduce
   intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics
   - SBT
   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).  Urine cx with GNRs.
   - MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
   - albumin 25 mg IV bolus
   - vanc/zosyn; consider linezolid if decompensates given history of VRE
   - sputum, urine, blood, stool cultures
   - will attempt to resite CVL, place a-line
   - check bladder pressure q6h
   - consider tap if pressures improve
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular reccs
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin for volume expansion
   - will consider paracentesis if bladder pressure increases
   - lactulose
   - liver reccs
   # CAD s/ MI: demand ischemia peri-operatively.
   - cont ASA, plavix, statin
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - CVVH today
   - renal reccs
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: TFs
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2111-1-23**] 07:44 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2111-1-23**] 07:45 PM

   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:
   Comments:

   Code status: Full code

Summary:

The patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]. He developed perioperative MI and was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis. The patient has multiple comorbidities, including respiratory failure, sepsis, PVD, and liver disease.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and requires weaning from the ventilator. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis/hypotension: The patient meets SIRS criteria and has multiple potential sources of infection, including pneumonia, lines, skin, and UTI. There is a risk of septic shock and organ failure.
3. PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient has a history of PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass. There is a risk of graft failure and infection.
4. HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient has cirrhosis and ascites, and a hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for HCC. There is a risk of liver failure and bleeding.
5. CAD s/ MI: The patient has a history of CAD and MI, and there is a risk of recurrent ischemia and infarction.
6. ESRD: The patient has ESRD and requires dialysis. There is a risk of acute kidney injury and dialysis-related complications.
7. Liver disease: The patient has liver disease and ascites, and there is a risk of liver failure and bleeding.

Based on the patient's comorbidities and clinical presentation, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, respiratory status, and laboratory results to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on January 12, 2111. He was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.6C, HR 91 bpm, BP 98/44 mmHg, RR 20 insp/min, SpO2 100%
* Respiratory support: Endotracheal tube, PCV+Assist mode, PEEP 10 cmH2O, FiO2 50%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 11 mmHg, Bladder pressure 16 mmHg
* Fluid balance: Total In 1,173 mL, Total Out 36 mL
* Laboratory results:
	+ WBC 10.4 K/uL
	+ Hct 33.7%
	+ Plt 295 K/uL
	+ Cr 3.7 mg/dL
	+ TropT 3.34 ng/mL
	+ TCO2 29 mmHg
	+ Glucose 185 mg/dL
	+ Other labs: PT/PTT/INR 17.0/32.8/1.5, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T 24//3.30, ALT/AST 6-26, Alk Phos/T Bili 63/0.3, Differential-Neuts 94.3%, Band 1.0%, Lymph 2.6%, Mono 2.4%, Eos 0.4%, Lactic Acid 0.8 mmol/L, LDH 103 IU/L, Ca++ 9.4 mg/dL, Mg++ 2.1 mg/dL, PO4 4.9 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Sepsis/hypotension: Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, leukocytosis, and peritoneal cavity as a likely source. Positive for SBP on tap prior to transfer. Other sources of infection include pneumonia, lines, skin, and UTI.
	+ MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
	+ Albumin 50 mg IV bolus
	+ Vanc/Zosyn; consider Linezolid if decompensates given history of VRE
	+ Sputum, urine, blood, and stool cultures
	+ Will attempt to resite CVL
	+ Check bladder pressure q6h
	+ Consider tap if pressures improve
* Respiratory failure: Was hypoxic on floor and hypercapneic on arrival to unit in setting of somnolence. ABG with acute respiratory acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung disease from smoking history.
	+ Continue to wean vent
	+ Vanc/Zosyn as above
	+ Will consider repeat therapeutic para if needed to reduce intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics
* PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: Will not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery. Also with R BKA and L AKA.
	+ Vascular reccs
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on [1-13] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI. History of HCV treatment at [Hospital1 12]. 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [2110-1-20] concerning for HCC. Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
	+ Albumin for volume expansion
	+ Will consider paracentesis if BPs stable
	+ Lactulose
	+ Liver reccs
* CAD s/ MI: Demand ischemia peri-operatively.
	+ Cont ASA, Plavix, statin
* ESRD: Last HD on [2111-1-21], on qMWF schedule.
	+ CVVH today
	+ Renal reccs

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis and septic shock: The patient's SIRS criteria and positive SBP on tap suggest a high risk of sepsis and septic shock.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and acidemia may worsen if not properly managed.
3. Hepatic decompensation: The patient's cirrhosis and ascites may lead to hepatic decompensation if not managed properly.
4. Renal failure: The patient's ESRD and history of hypotension may lead to renal failure if not properly managed.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's CAD and history of MI may lead to cardiovascular complications such as demand ischemia and cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Infection: The patient's multiple lines and grafts may lead to infection if not properly managed.
7. Bleeding: The patient's history of perioperative MI and bleeding may lead to bleeding complications if not properly managed.

It is essential to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition closely to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p
   perioperative MI and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD, underwent
   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now
   transferred to MICU for management of hypotension and question sepsis.

   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Improved with 1.6L

   - will consider repeat therapeutic para if needed to reduce
   intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics- currently
   bladder pressures 15

   # Sepsis/hypotension:  Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).  Urine cx with Klebsiella.
   - MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
   - albumin 25 mg IV bolus
   - antibiotics as above; consider linezolid if decompensates given
   history of VRE
   - sputum, blood cx pending
   - check bladder pressure q12
   - consider tap if pressures improve
   # PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis:  Will
   not use this graft for ABGs per discussion with surgery.  Also with R
   BKA and L AKA.
   - vascular reccs
   # HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass:  Has cirrhosis and ascites with 4L tap on
   [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI.  History of HCV treatment
   at [**Hospital1 12**].  1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for
   HCC.  Normal AFP; plan for repeat u/s in 3 months per liver.
   - albumin for volume expansion
   - will consider paracentesis if bladder pressure increases
   - lactulose
   - liver reccs
   # CAD s/ MI: demand ischemia peri-operatively.
   - cont ASA, plavix, statin
   # ESRD: Last HD on [**2111-1-21**], on qMWF schedule.
   - CVVH today- attempt fluid off as tolerated
   - renal reccs

   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).  Urine cx with Klebsiella.

Summary:

The patient, a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, is admitted to the MICU for management of hypotension and suspected sepsis. He has undergone left brachial to radial bypass surgery, complicated by perioperative MI, and has a history of HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, and CAD. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He has developed a productive cough, and his respiratory acidosis is likely exacerbated by his large abdomen, pleural effusions, and underlying lung disease.

The patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, leukocytosis, and peritoneal cavity as a likely source of infection. He has a positive SBP on tap and has developed a Klebsiella pneumoniae infection, as evidenced by his urine culture. He has also developed cellulitis around his graft site and has a history of VRE.

The patient's medical team is working to manage his multiple comorbidities, including sepsis, hypotension, respiratory failure, and liver disease. They are planning to continue to wean his vent, change his antibiotics, and consider repeat therapeutic paracentesis to reduce intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis and septic shock: The patient's infection is likely to worsen if not properly managed, leading to septic shock and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and hypoxia may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to further respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Liver disease: The patient's HCV cirrhosis and liver mass may worsen if not properly managed, leading to liver failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Renal failure: The patient's ESRD and recent HD may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further renal failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's CAD and recent MI may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further cardiovascular complications and potentially life-threatening outcomes.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis and septic shock with antibiotics and fluid resuscitation.
2. Continue to wean the patient's vent and improve his respiratory mechanics with repeat therapeutic paracentesis.
3. Monitor the patient's liver function and consider further management of his HCV cirrhosis and liver mass.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and consider further management of his ESRD.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and consider further management of his CAD and recent MI.

Summary:

The patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on 2111-1-12. He developed perioperative MI and was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and sepsis. The patient is currently intubated and has respiratory failure, sepsis, and hypotension. He has multiple sources of infection, including peritoneal cavity, pneumonia, lines, skin, and UTI. The patient also has liver cirrhosis with ascites and a hypoechoic liver lesion concerning for HCC.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen due to his underlying lung disease, pleural effusions, and abdominal distension. He may require prolonged mechanical ventilation and may be at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to progress if not properly managed, leading to organ dysfunction and potential mortality. He may require aggressive antibiotics and supportive care to control his infection.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely to worsen if not properly managed, leading to organ hypoperfusion and potential multi-organ failure. He may require vasopressors and inotropes to maintain adequate blood pressure.
4. Liver Failure: The patient's liver cirrhosis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further liver failure and potential mortality. He may require close monitoring of his liver function and potential liver transplantation.
5. Kidney Failure: The patient's ESRD may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further kidney failure and potential mortality. He may require close monitoring of his kidney function and potential dialysis.
6. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's CAD and perioperative MI may lead to further cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and potential mortality.
7. Wound Complications: The patient's PVD and bypass graft may lead to wound complications, such as infection, dehiscence, and potential mortality.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's ascites and liver cirrhosis may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and potential mortality.
9. Neurological Complications: The patient's sepsis and hypotension may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, and potential mortality.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential medical complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including hypotension, respiratory failure, HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and s/p perioperative MI and PVD. The patient is currently admitted to the MICU for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**].

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 525 mL, and a PEEP of 10 cmH2O.
* Sepsis/hypotension: The patient is receiving pressors and has a blood pressure of 87/45 mmHg.
* Severe PVD: The patient has a left brachial to radial bypass and is at risk for further complications.
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient has a hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for HCC, and his AFP is normal.
* CAD s/ MI: The patient had a perioperative MI and is on ASA, Plavix, and statin.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 17.3-19.1 K/uL
* Hct: 27.3-28.2%
* Plt: 290-252 K/uL
* Cr: 4.0-4.3 mg/dL
* TropT: 3.64-3.30 ng/mL
* TCO2: 27-22 mmHg
* Glucose: 111-96 mg/dL

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and respiratory failure may be secondary to sepsis, and further evaluation is needed to determine the source of the infection.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and hypotension may be secondary to pneumonia, and further evaluation is needed to determine if the patient has a pulmonary infection.
3. CVL: The patient's hypotension and respiratory failure may be secondary to a central venous line infection, and further evaluation is needed to determine if the patient has a CVL infection.
4. Skin infection: The patient's hypotension and respiratory failure may be secondary to a skin infection, and further evaluation is needed to determine if the patient has a skin infection.
5. UTI: The patient's hypotension and respiratory failure may be secondary to a urinary tract infection, and further evaluation is needed to determine if the patient has a UTI.
6. Liver failure: The patient's liver cirrhosis and hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for HCC may lead to liver failure, and further evaluation is needed to determine the patient's liver function.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient's CAD and perioperative MI may lead to further cardiac complications, and further evaluation is needed to determine the patient's cardiac function.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Weaning off mechanical ventilation
2. Removing volume with CVVHD
3. Monitoring for signs of sepsis
4. Further evaluation of the patient's liver function
5. Continuing ASA, Plavix, and statin for CAD
6. Continuing dialysis therapy
7. Further evaluation of the patient's respiratory function

In summary, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications. The patient's potential medical complications include sepsis, pneumonia, CVL, skin infection, UTI, liver failure, and cardiac complications, and further evaluation is needed to determine the patient's underlying condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent a left brachial to radial bypass procedure on [**2111-1-12**]. He was transferred to the MICU due to hypotension and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is critical, with ongoing hypotension, respiratory failure, and potential sepsis. He is receiving pressors, vasopressors, and antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem. The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 525 mL and a plateau pressure of 33 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of liver dysfunction, with elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. His kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 4.3 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 108 mg/dL. His electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia.

The patient's physical examination reveals tachycardia, hypotension, and tachypnea. His abdomen is soft and non-tender, with bowel sounds present. His extremities are cool, and his skin is cool to the touch.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and respiratory failure may be secondary to sepsis, which can lead to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's kidney function is already impaired, and further decline in kidney function can lead to AKI.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver dysfunction can lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause altered mental status, seizures, and coma.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and potential sepsis make him at risk for developing pneumonia.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's CAD and recent MI make him at risk for cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, and cardiogenic shock.
6. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and presence of central lines and catheters make him at risk for developing infections, including bloodstream infections and urinary tract infections.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's liver dysfunction and potential sepsis make him at risk for developing gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status. Aggressive management of his respiratory and cardiovascular status is necessary to prevent further deterioration. Additionally, prompt treatment of any potential infections and close monitoring of his liver and kidney function are crucial to prevent further complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass. He developed perioperative MI and PVD, and was transferred to the MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: He was hypoxic on the floor and hypercapneic on arrival to the unit. His ABG showed acute respiratory acidosis and acidemia. He improved with 1.6L paracentesis and was extubated this morning.
* Sepsis/hypotension: He has urosepsis and a positive SBP on tap. He is being treated with vancomycin and meropenem for 7 days, and may need linezolid if he decompensates.
* PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The graft will not be used for ABGs, and he has R BKA and L AKA.
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: He has cirrhosis and ascites, with a 4L tap on [**1-13**] associated with hypotension and NSTEMI. He has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US [**2110-1-20**] concerning for HCC. He will have repeat US in 3 months.
* CAD s/ MI: He had demand ischemia peri-operatively and is being treated with ASA, Plavix, and statin.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and acidemia may worsen if his respiratory status is not closely monitored and managed.
* Sepsis/hypotension: The patient's urosepsis and positive SBP on tap increase his risk of developing septic shock and multi-organ failure.
* PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient's graft will not be used for ABGs, and he has R BKA and L AKA, which may increase his risk of developing further complications.
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient's cirrhosis and ascites increase his risk of developing further complications, including liver failure and portal hypertension.
* CAD s/ MI: The patient's history of CAD and MI increase his risk of developing further cardiac complications, including cardiogenic shock and arrhythmias.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient, a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD, was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass. He developed perioperative MI and was transferred to the ICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis. The patient has respiratory failure, sepsis, and hypotension. He is on mechanical ventilation, continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH), and receiving antibiotics for urosepsis. The patient has a history of HCV treatment and has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US, concerning for HCC.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and hypercapnea may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise.
2. Sepsis and hypotension: The patient's sepsis and hypotension may progress, leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Urosepsis: The patient's urosepsis may not respond to current antibiotic treatment, leading to further complications.
4. Liver failure: The patient's liver cirrhosis and hypoechoic liver lesion may worsen, leading to liver failure.
5. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen, leading to acute kidney injury or further decline in renal function.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's CAD and history of MI may lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's ascites and liver cirrhosis may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
8. Infection complications: The patient's immunocompromised state and history of HCV treatment may increase the risk of secondary infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust mechanical ventilation settings as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis and hypotension with antibiotics and vasopressors.
3. Consider repeat therapeutic paracentesis to reduce intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and consider repeat US in 3 months for further evaluation of the liver lesion.
5. Continue to manage the patient's chronic kidney disease with CVVH and consider adjusting the treatment plan as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further cardiac complications.
7. Consider prophylactic antibiotics to prevent secondary infections.
8. Consider consulting with a liver specialist to further evaluate the patient's liver lesion and treatment options.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 7614**] is a 55 year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD s/p

   left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**] complicated by perioperative
   MI, was transferred to medicine of comorbidities, and is now

   arrival to unit in setting of somnolence.  ABG with acute respiratory
   acidosis, acidemia, likely aggravated by large abdomen, pleural
   effusions, muscular weakness from critical illness, and underlying lung
   disease from smoking history, though does not carry copd diagnosis.
   Also with productive cough developing during hospitalization c/f pna.
   Intubated after failing trial of bipap.  Improved with 1.6L

   bladder pressures 15

   leukocytosis, and periotneal cavity as likely source.  Positive for SBP
   on tap on [**2111-1-23**] prior to transfer.  Other sources of infection include
   pneumonia (productive sputum), lines (R subclav, L subclav HD), skins
   (cellulitis around graft site), and UTI (purulent material drained
   after foley placement).  Decreased venous return may also be
   contributing given ascites.  Dressings for lines last changed on [**2111-1-17**]
   (triple lumen) and [**2111-1-21**] (HD).  Urine cx with Klebsiella.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass, which was complicated by perioperative MI. He is currently in the ICU for management of hypotension and suspected sepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode. His ABG shows acute respiratory acidosis and acidemia. He has a productive cough and is at risk for pneumonia.
* Sepsis/hypotension: He meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, leukocytosis, and peritoneal cavity as a likely source. He has positive blood cultures and urine cultures, and his dressing for lines has not been changed recently.
* PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: He has a history of PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass. He has a right 4th PIP osteomyelitis and is at risk for further complications.
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: He has cirrhosis and ascites with a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US, concerning for HCC.
* CAD s/ MI: He has a history of CAD and MI, and is at risk for further ischemia.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 17.3
* Hct: 27.3
* Plt: 290
* Cr: 4.0
* TropT: 3.64
* TCO2: 24
* Glucose: 111
* Lactic Acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 4.0 g/dL
* LDH: 141 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.2 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.1 mg/dL
* PO4: 2.7 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Calcium Gluconate (CRRT)
* Midazolam (Versed)
* Fentanyl (Concentrate)
* KCl (CRRT)
* Pantoprazole (Protonix)
* Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis)
* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Vancomycin
* Meropenem
* Albumin (25 mg IV bolus)
* Linezolid (considered if decompensates)

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning of vent
* Changing Zosyn to Meropenem
* Repeat therapeutic paracentesis if needed to reduce intra-abdominal pressures and improve respiratory mechanics
* SBT
* Attempt volume off for improved oxygenation via CVVH
* MAPs > 60, SVO2 > 70%
* Albumin for volume expansion
* Lactulose
* Liver reccs
* Renal reccs
* Consider linezolid if decompensates

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory acidosis.
* Sepsis/hypotension: Septic shock, organ failure, and death.
* PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: Infection, sepsis, and amputation.
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: Liver failure, HCC, and portal hypertension.
* CAD s/ MI: Ischemia, infarction, and heart failure.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and ensure optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. The patient was admitted to the MICU for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass. The patient is currently extubated and doing well post-extubation.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Tmax: 36.6C (97.9F)
* Tcurrent: 36.6C (97.9F)
* HR: 104 bpm (75-104 bpm)
* BP: 123/55 mmHg (72-124/72-80 mmHg)
* RR: 26 inspirations per minute (11-32 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 17.3-19.1 K/uL
* Hct: 27.3-31.7%
* Plt: 290-201 K/uL
* Cr: 4.0-4.3 mg/dL
* TropT: 3.64-3.30 ng/mL
* TCO2: 24-22 mmHg
* Glucose: 111-94 mg/dL
* Other lab results are within normal limits.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Sepsis/hypotension: The patient is able to wean off pressors, but the possibility of pneumonia, CVL, skin, and UTI (purulent material drained after foley placement) needs to be considered.
* Severe PVD: The patient underwent left brachial to radial bypass and has R BKA, L AKA.
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US, concerning for HCC, and will need repeat US in 3 months.
* CAD s/ MI: The patient has demand ischemia peri-operatively and will continue ASA, plavix, and statin.
* Cellulitis: The patient will continue vancomycin.
* ESRD: The patient will have regular HD on MWF schedule and may require CVVH.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis/hypotension: Pneumonia, CVL, skin, and UTI (purulent material drained after foley placement)
* Severe PVD: Ischemia, gangrene, and amputation
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: Hepatocellular carcinoma, liver failure, and portal hypertension
* CAD s/ MI: Myocardial infarction, heart failure, and cardiac arrest
* Cellulitis: Worsening infection, sepsis, and organ failure
* ESRD: Kidney failure, electrolyte imbalance, and cardiovascular complications.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, lab results, and clinical status to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal care.

* Cardiac complications: The patient's enlarged heart on CXR and possible superadded infection can lead to cardiac complications such as cardiomyopathy or cardiac arrhythmias.
* Kidney disease progression: The patient's chronic renal failure can progress to end-stage renal disease if not managed properly.
* Infection: The patient's respiratory culture results show mixed bacterial types and yeast, which can lead to infection and sepsis.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis and possible superadded infection can lead to gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding or perforation.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old man with HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD who was admitted for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass surgery. He developed perioperative MI, was transferred to medicine for comorbidities, and is now in the MICU for management of hypotension and urosepsis. The patient has respiratory failure, sepsis/hypotension, PVD, and HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass.

Key Findings:

* The patient's blood pressure dropped at 8 PM, and he was given 25 gm albumin without much improvement.
* He was taken off pressors and CVVH, and started back on levophed and attempted to wean down, with no mental status changes with low BPs.
* The patient has a large abdomen, pleural effusions, and muscular weakness from critical illness, which may be contributing to his respiratory acidosis and acidemia.
* He has urosepsis and positive for SBP on tap prior to transfer.
* The patient has a 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion on US, concerning for HCC, and normal AFP.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and acidemia may worsen if not managed properly.
* Sepsis/hypotension: The patient's urosepsis and positive SBP on tap may lead to further decompensation if not treated promptly.
* PVD/Left brachial to radial bypass/Right 4th PIP osteomyelitis: The patient's vascular recs may be compromised if not managed properly.
* HCV cirrhosis/Liver mass: The patient's liver disease may worsen if not managed properly, and the 1.8 cm hypoechoic liver lesion may be a sign of HCC.
* CAD s/ MI: The patient's demand ischemia peri-operatively may lead to further cardiac complications if not managed properly.
* ESRD: The patient's kidney disease may worsen if not managed properly, and CVVH may not be effective in removing toxins.

Recommendations:

* Continue vancomycin and meropenem for urosepsis.
* Maintain MAPs > 60 and SVO2 > 70%.
* Consider linezolid if the patient decompensates, given his history of VRE.
* Monitor the patient's sputum and blood cultures.
* Continue ASA, plavix, and statin for CAD s/ MI.
* Attempt fluid off on CVVH as tolerated.
* Monitor the patient's liver function and consider paracentesis if bladder pressure increases.
* Continue lactulose and albumin PRN for volume expansion.
* Consider repeat US in 3 months for liver lesion.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a complex medical history, including HCV cirrhosis, ESRD, DM, CAD, and PVD. He was admitted to the ICU for worsening PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**]. He developed hypotension and sepsis, and was treated with vasopressors and antibiotics.

Current vital signs:

* Temperature: 36.7C (98F)
* Heart rate: 102 bpm (93-120 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 91/72 mmHg (76/85 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 19 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* SpO2: 99%

Laboratory results:

* White blood cell count: 17.3 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 277 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 3.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 22 mmol/L
* Sodium: 139 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.4 mmol/L
* Calcium: 8.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 3.64 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 4.0 g/dL
* LDH: 141 IU/L

Assessment and plan:

* The patient is critically ill with multi-organ dysfunction, including respiratory failure, sepsis, and hypotension.
* He is receiving vasopressors and antibiotics for sepsis and hypotension.
* He has a history of PVD and underwent left brachial to radial bypass on [**2111-1-12**].
* He has a liver mass concerning for HCC and is scheduled for repeat ultrasound in 3 months.
* He has CAD and s/p MI with demand ischemia peri-operatively.
* He has ESRD and is on MWF dialysis schedule.
* He has cellulitis and is receiving vancomycin.

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis and septic shock
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Liver failure
* Intestinal obstruction
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Stress ulcer
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
* Adjust vasopressors and antibiotics as needed to manage sepsis and hypotension.
* Consider further evaluation and treatment for the liver mass concerning for HCC.
* Continue to manage CAD and s/p MI with demand ischemia peri-operatively.
* Monitor for signs of AKI and adjust dialysis schedule as needed.
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
* Monitor for signs of cardiac arrhythmias and adjust medication as needed.
* Monitor for signs of liver failure and adjust treatment as needed.
* Monitor for signs of intestinal obstruction and adjust treatment as needed.
* Monitor for signs of DVT and adjust treatment as needed.
* Monitor for signs of stress ulcer and adjust treatment as needed.
* Monitor for signs of VAP and adjust treatment as needed.
